No regressions noted on x86_64 Ivy Bridge.
No regressions noted on i686.

WFM Thinkpad X250, `dnf system-upgrade`d from F25 to F26

bugs.title: Kernel 4.11.3 will not boot on UP Board SBC system.

bugzilla.short_desc: Kernel 4.11.3 will not boot on UP Board SBC system.

long_desc.thetext:
Description of problem:
UP Board SBC will not boot current 4.11.3 kernel from Fedora 25 updates.

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
4.11.3

How reproducible:
Boot the system from power on and select 4.11.3 kernel from boot menu.  System freezes immediately with blank screen and no response to keyboard or mouse.  Power off and than power on is required to restart system. 

Steps to Reproduce:
1.Power on system
2.Select 4.11.1 kernel, or if it is the first selection, do nothing and wait for the timeout. 
3.System freezes with blank screen.

Actual results:
Blank screen after selecting the specific kernel from the boot menu.

Expected results:
Scrolling of text indicating that the boot process is continuing.

Additional info:
System is an UP Board SBC (Single Board Computer) with 4 GB of memory and 64 GB of eMMC.  See http://up-shop.org/up-boards/44-up-board-4gb-ram-64-gb-emmc.html
This system boots from the eMMC.  I have been running this board as a server starting with Fedora 24 and now with Fedora 25.  It has worked with all kernels from these distributions until I install this new 4.11.3 kernel.
A type-pos: The kernel version here is 4.11.3, not 4.11.1.

I installed the new kernel-4.11.3-202.fc25.x86_64 package and rebooted.  Received the same failed result: system freezes after selecting the kernel at boot time.

Here is the output from lsmod running the 4.10.17-200.fc25.x86_64 kernel:

Same issue based on Mainboard "asrock fatal1ty z68 professional gen3". The system boots from SSD.

Recently upgraded from Fedora 24 to 25 and ran into same issue with Asrock P67 Extreme4 Gen3 with BIOS 2.20 (most recent from 2012). Xeon E3-1230v2 CPU.

If I remove "quiet" from the boot parameters, only the line "Probing EDD (edd=off to disable)... ok" appears. A blinking cursor appears directly below it and boot goes no further. nouveau is blacklisted.

Previous kernels 4.8.6-300.fc25.x86_64 and 4.10.10-100.fc24.x86_64 boot without issue.

There's also a recent support question on fedora question related to the kernel version and nouveau, which may be conflating multiple issues, but another user "nullcat" responding to thread posted his lspci which was similar to my hardware. We both have "Xeon E3-1200" processors. https://ask.fedoraproject.org/en/question/106433/kernel-panic-in-4113-using-nouveau-driver/

Thanks for the serial output. This seems like it might be related to bf7696a12071 ("acpi: lpss: call pwm_add_table() for BSW PWM device") ?

Hi,

(In reply to Laura Abbott from comment #7)
> Thanks for the serial output. This seems like it might be related to
> bf7696a12071 ("acpi: lpss: call pwm_add_table() for BSW PWM device") ?

Ack, I think this is caused by the UP board having both its PWM controllers enabled, the Baytrail code path from which I copied this likely has the same issue, but there are probably no boards with both PWM controllers enabled. I will try to create a patch fixing this tomorrow.

Regards,

Hans

Created attachment 1294736
ACPI / LPSS: Only call pwm_add_table for the first PWM controller

Ok so I decided to just go ahead and whip up a patch right away. Laura can you perhaps do a test-kernel build with this patch added for the reporter to test ?

Thank you very much!
I'll try to compile the kernel with this patch myself if you'd like?

Hello,
Question: which kernel version does this patch apply to? I've installed kernel-4.11.8-200.fc25.src.rpm but there's no function called "byt_pwm_setup" in acpi_lpss.c. Thanks!

Hi,

(In reply to Joel Stienlet from comment #11)
> Hello,
> Question: which kernel version does this patch apply to? I've installed
> kernel-4.11.8-200.fc25.src.rpm but there's no function called
> "byt_pwm_setup" in acpi_lpss.c. Thanks!

Its against 4.12, for 4.11 you can just drop the hunk of the patch which is touching byt_pwm_setup.

Regards,

Hans

The patch is working, the kernel boots again :)
Thank you very much Hans and Laura!
Best regards,
J.Stienlet

(In reply to Joel Stienlet from comment #13)
> The patch is working, the kernel boots again :)
> Thank you very much Hans and Laura!

Great, thank you for testing. I've submitted the patch upstream now.

Is a patched packaged version of a kernel with this patch fix going to be available soon?  I only ask because it has been some years since I recompiled a kernel.  It is not that I am not unwilling to recompile the kernel, but it will be very much a relearning experience for me.  The other issue in my mind is will this patch be included in the release of Fedora 26?

In the meantime you can download my version (4.11.8 fc25) from google drive:
https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B-qaF4FonWwLTlpuYXlhUGoza0k
(be careful, I haven't inserted anything nasty, but you only have my word for it...)

(In reply to Joel Stienlet from comment #16)
> In the meantime you can download my version (4.11.8 fc25) from google drive:
> https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B-qaF4FonWwLTlpuYXlhUGoza0k
> (be careful, I haven't inserted anything nasty, but you only have my word
> for it...)

Joel I appreciate the offer, but no thank you.  The Up-Board is a production system and I need to be careful.  In any case, I need to learn again how to compile kernels. :-)

(In reply to Hans de Goede from comment #14)
> (In reply to Joel Stienlet from comment #13)
> > The patch is working, the kernel boots again :)
> > Thank you very much Hans and Laura!
> 
> Great, thank you for testing. I've submitted the patch upstream now.

I have just finished my own process of patching, compiling and installing a version of the 4.11.8 kernel with this patch.  I can report success booting the UP Board with this patched kernel.  I have no new problems to report and can only hope that some version of this patch makes it into the final iteration of Fedora 26.  Thank you for your help.
I put the patch into the tree. It should show up in 4.11.10 which is scheduled to be released from upstream Wednesday and available in Fedora sometime shortly afterwards.

The 4,11.10 kernel is apparently not included on the Cinnamon install ISO and is maybe not present on any of the other Fedora 26 installs.  is there an easier way to install Fedora 26 without having to do something like a dnf distro-sync on top of an install of Fedora 25?

Hello Bill,
I'll try to make a custom install dvd with pungi and tell you if it worked. That will not be easier if you only have one to install, but definitely faster if you have a bunch of them.

(In reply to Joel Stienlet from comment #30)
> Hello Bill,
> I'll try to make a custom install dvd with pungi and tell you if it worked.
> That will not be easier if you only have one to install, but definitely
> faster if you have a bunch of them.

Joel, Thanks for the suggestion.  Pungi is a new app for me, but I am going to try it out.  I have a few of these Up Board SBCs and I need to have a way to install Fedora 26 if the user wants to do so.  Google is a worthless search engine sometimes in finding such tools....

Works on a fresh f26 install

karma: +1

No regressions noted on x86_64 Ivy Bridge.
No regressions noted on i686.
works for me (Laptop with AMD E-450 APU)
Works for me, x86_64, GNOME (CPU: Intel Core2 Quad Q8400, RAM: 8 GiB, GPU: AMD RV635).
WFM Thinkpad X250, `dnf system-upgrade`d from F25 to F26

bugs.title: CVE-2017-10810 Kernel: virtio-gpu: memory leakage while creating gpu object

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2017-10810 Kernel: virtio-gpu: memory leakage while creating gpu object

long_desc.thetext:
Linux kernel built with the VirtIO GPU driver(CONFIG_DRM_VIRTIO_GPU) support
is vulnerable to a memory leakage issue. It could occur while creating a virtio
gpu object in virtio_gpu_object_create().

A user/process could use this flaw to leak host kernel memory potentially
resulting in DoS.

Upstream patch:
---------------
  -> https://git.kernel.org/linus/385aee965b4e4c36551c362a334378d2985b722a

Reference:
----------
  -> http://www.openwall.com/lists/oss-security/2017/07/07/2

Acknowledgments:

Name: Li Qiang (Qihoo 360 Gear Team)

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 1468024]

Statement:

This issue does not affect the versions of the kernel package as shipped with
Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5, 6 and Red Hat Enterprise MRG 2.

This issue affects the version of Linux kernel as shipped with
Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.

This has been rated as having Low security impact and is not currently
planned to be addressed in future updates. For additional information, refer
to the Red Hat Enterprise Linux Life Cycle:
https://access.redhat.com/support/policy/updates/errata/.
kernel-4.11.10-100.fc24 has been pushed to the Fedora 24 stable repository. If problems still persist, please make note of it in this bug report.
kernel-4.11.10-200.fc25 has been pushed to the Fedora 25 stable repository. If problems still persist, please make note of it in this bug report.

is vulnerable to a memory leakage issue. It could occur while creating a virtio

This is an automatically created tracking bug!  It was created to ensure
that one or more security vulnerabilities are fixed in affected versions
of Fedora.

For comments that are specific to the vulnerability please use bugs filed
against the "Security Response" product referenced in the "Blocks" field.

For more information see:
http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Security/TrackingBugs

When submitting as an update, use the fedpkg template provided in the next
comment(s).  This will include the bug IDs of this tracking bug as well as
the relevant top-level CVE bugs.

Please also mention the CVE IDs being fixed in the RPM changelog and the
fedpkg commit message.

NOTE: this issue affects multiple supported versions of Fedora. While only
one tracking bug has been filed, please correct all affected versions at
the same time.  If you need to fix the versions independent of each other,
you may clone this bug as appropriate.

Reproducers, if any, will remain confidential and never be made public, unless done so by the security team.

[bug automatically created by: add-tracking-bugs]

Use the following template to for the 'fedpkg update' request to submit an
update for this issue as it contains the top-level parent bug(s) as well as
this tracking bug.  This will ensure that all associated bugs get updated
when new packages are pushed to stable.

=====

# bugfix, security, enhancement, newpackage (required)
type=security

# testing, stable
request=testing

# Bug numbers: 1234,9876
bugs=1468023,1468024

# Description of your update
notes=Security fix for CVE-2017-10810

# Enable request automation based on the stable/unstable karma thresholds
autokarma=True
stable_karma=3
unstable_karma=-3

# Automatically close bugs when this marked as stable
close_bugs=True

# Suggest that users restart after update
suggest_reboot=False

======

Additionally, you may opt to use the bodhi web interface to submit updates:

https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/new
